newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: U.S. soldier jailed for killing Korean prostitute.
newsitem.headline: U.S. soldier jailed for killing Korean prostitute.

text.p: A South Korean court sentenced a U.S. serviceman to 15 years in jail on Thursday for murdering a Korean prostitute in a case that sparked renewed protests over the presence of U.S. forces in the country.
Eric Munnich, 22, from Chicago, confessed at his trial to stabbing the woman to death in a drunken rage during a quarrel over payment for sexual services.
A defence lawyer, who declined to be named, quoted Munnich as saying the sentence was too heavy and he would appeal on the grounds that the prostitute had begun the fight.

Prosecutors had demanded life in jail, but the judge explained he had handed down a lesser sentence because Munnich was drunk at the time of the murder and emotionally unstable as a new arrival in South Korea.

Resentment over the special legal status of the 37,000 American troops in the country was inflamed when U.S. military authorities rejected a South Korean request to hand him over to Korean custody pending his trial.
Munnich is still in U.S. military detention, but if his conviction is upheld he would serve his sentence in a Korean jail.

Several hundred protesters demonstrated outside the U.S. embassy in Seoul after a funeral service for the prostitute. The commander of U.S. forces in South Korea, General John Tillely, called the murder "tragic and nonsensical".
U.S. forces are stationed in South Korea to deter aggression by North Korea. The two Koreas have been technically at war since their 1950-53 conflict ended in a truce.
The body of Lee Ki-sun, 44, was discovered in a boarding house near a U.S. military base north of Seoul in September.
